results.headline: In a Mob Family, Blood Feuds Span Generations
results.summary_short: The saga “Gangs of Wasseypur” is five hours — and then some — of gliding camera moves, brutal action and dizzying revenge plotting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gangs of Wasseypur

results.headline: Aimless Adventures of a Hip Narcissist
results.summary_short: “Appropriate Behavior” centers on a willful young bisexual woman in Brooklyn who embarks erratically on sexual adventures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Appropriate Behavior

results.headline: Focusing on the Margins of Society
results.summary_short: Adam Rifkin’s new documentary follows Giuseppe Andrews as he rounds up his neighbors at a trailer park (and assorted transients) to shoot his latest film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Giuseppe Makes a Movie

results.headline: Ruben Ostlund’s ‘Involuntary,’ ‘Play’ and ‘The Guitar Mongoloid’
results.summary_short: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is holding a retrospective of Ruben Ostlund’s movies through Jan. 22.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of De Ofrivilliga

results.headline: A Dance Instructor Amid Twists and Reversals
results.summary_short: In “Match,” Patrick Stewart plays a dance professor at Juilliard who becomes involved in a confrontation with a woman interviewing him for her dissertation and her husband.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Match

results.headline: Another Avenging Rampage
results.summary_short: Liam Neeson returns as the retired government agent Bryan Mills in “Taken 3.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taken 3

results.headline: Seeking Solace Elsewhere, Before Encountering It at Home
results.summary_short: “Valley of Saints” tells the story of two men whose plans are disrupted by a military curfew and whose friendship is threatened by a shared love interest.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valley of Saints

results.headline: Finding Her Way Back in Small, Slow Steps
results.summary_short: In “Something, Anything,” a young newlywed disrupts her closest relationships as she tries to put her life back together after a traumatic loss.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Something, Anything

results.headline: Tripping Over the Hazy Line Between Fiction and Reality
results.summary_short: Raya Martin and Mark Peranson’s “La Última Película” is a goofy, dazzling riff on Dennis Hopper’s ambitious if flawed picture, “The Last Movie.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La última película

results.headline: Codes and Vendettas, Frozen in Time
results.summary_short: A Civil War legacy cascades through the backwoods of North Carolina in the 1970s in “The World Made Straight,” an overcooked adaptation of a Ron Rash novel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The World Made Straight

results.headline: When Traveling Through Time, Pack a Change of Identities
results.summary_short: Based on a short story by the science-fiction writer Robert A. Heinlein, “Predestination” tracks the journeys of a Temporal Agent assigned to right wrongs before they happen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Predestination

results.headline: Death Watch on a Dutch Farm
results.summary_short: In Nanouk Leopold’s “It’s All So Quiet,” a middle-aged farmer waits on his bedridden father while making plans for when he dies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's All So Quiet

results.headline: A Family Fractured by the Holocaust
results.summary_short: In “Farewell Herr Schwarz,” Yael Reuveny follows the trail of relatives who were torn apart.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farewell Herr Shwarz

results.headline: Captive, and Not Just to the Internet
results.summary_short: In “Dark Summer,” a teenager becomes the victim of his online obsession.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dark Summer

results.headline: Challenging Corruption in the Niger Delta
results.summary_short: “Black November,” a blood-for-oil drama directed by Jeta Amata, follows a Nigerian activist who mobilized opposition after a deadly explosion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black November

results.headline: A Literary Triumvirate of Love and Lust
results.summary_short: “Beloved Sisters” imagines a fraught ménage à trois among the German poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller and the sisters Charlotte von Lengefeld and Caroline von Lengefeld.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beloved Sisters

results.display_title: The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death
results.headline: A Ghost With a Grudge (Watch Out, Kids!)
results.summary_short: In “The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death,” a ghost with a vendetta against the young leaves behind the Edwardian setting of its predecessor for 1941.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woman in Black 2: Angel of Death

results.headline: Finding Meaning in a Dish
results.summary_short: Ian Cheney’s documentary “The Search for General Tso” is about history, heritage and struggle as much as about a certain chicken dish popular in Chinese restaurants.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Search for General Tso

results.headline: Heating Oil Mixed With Trouble
results.summary_short: A family, its heating-oil business and New York are at the center of J. C. Chandor’s “A Most Violent Year.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Most Violent Year

results.headline: On, Then Off, Now On Again
results.summary_short: “The Interview” mainly extends the bro-com, as practiced by James Franco and Seth Rogen, into new geopolitical markets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Interview
